p: The scale predator Rhyzobius lophanthae Blaisdell (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae) was released in Guam in 2005 [ 31]. We have identified three limitations to the predatory success of this animal. First, the A. yasumatsui individuals are so small that they can infest locations on Cycas organ surfaces that the relatively large predator cannot access [ 39, 40]. Second, the predator tends to avoid the plants’ lowest stratum for unknown reasons such that A. yasumatsui infestations are uncontrolled on leaf, stem, and root surfaces near the ground [ 41]. Third, the olfactory signals from A. yasumatsui are less attractive to the predator when the infested leaves are from seedlings rather than adults [ 42]. These and other phenomena have limited this predator’s success in protecting the tree host from A. yasumatsui damage.
